text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
Congress finds as follows:

Tracking the location of vehicles and the identities of owners for the purpose of taxation, fines
			 or fees has the potential to be misused, and such collected data could be
			 hacked or used for privacy-invading purposes.

Government and corporate websites are frequently hacked, and driver-tracking databases may be no
			 more invulnerable to hacking; to the advantage of criminals, stalkers, and
			 identity thieves.

GPS tracking enables the technology for automatic speeding, parking and other traffic tickets,
			 charging variable tax rates due to the time of day or other factors,
			 including characterizing driving behavior from acceleration and braking
			 speed, evasive maneuvers such as swerving to avoid a child or deer in the
			 road, or driving in what the Government may believe is a

GPS tracking schemes may require vehicle owners to maintain bank accounts for the debiting of
			 resultant fees. This may be a hardship for many low-income vehicle owners,
			 as well as opening new hacking vulnerabilities for bank accounts of
			 vehicle owners.

The existing gas tax is a rare example of a user fee, whereby vehicle owners pay for the roads they
			 use when purchasing fuel. The tax has successfully provided necessary
			 funding for many decades.

There are far less intrusive ways than location-based tracking to get electric vehicle and hybrid
			 owners to pay for their road usage.

Vehicle owners must not be required to surrender their Fourth Amendment rights and be tracked
			 everywhere as a condition of driving on public roads.

The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against
			 unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated, and no warrants

text.#text: Amendment IV of the United States Constitution states

It is the purpose of this Act to prohibit the replacement or supplementation of the Federal
			 gasoline excise tax with any tax or fee based upon vehicle location or
			 distance traveled, whether determined by global positioning satellite
			 (GPS), license plate reading cameras or any other method of determining
			 owner registration or identity information, and vehicle location or
			 distance traveled.

header.#text: Prohibition of a GPS, location or mileage based tax

text.#text:
It is contrary to the public policy of the United States to require the placement or use of any
			 GPS, location, distance tracking system, or any other system to collect
			 identities of vehicle owners by any remote means such as license plate
			 reading cameras, radio frequency identification (RFID) devices or by any
			 other means.

The Federal gasoline excise tax may not be replaced or supplemented with any tax, fee or fine based
			 upon vehicle location or distance traveled, whether determined by global
			 positioning satellite (GPS), cameras that read license plates or any other
			 method of determining vehicle location, distance traveled or registration
			 and identity data.

No motor vehicle may be required to have any device on board the vehicle or to transmit data to any
			 off board device which tracks or records, collects, stores, transmits and
			 location, distance, or registration or driver identity information.

header.#text: Limitations on vehicle-to-vehicle and vehicle-to-infrastructure communications

text.#text:
No public funds may be used to study or implement or require the use of any method of tracking or
			 reporting vehicle movement or location for the purpose of taxes, user
			 fees, traffic fines, accident investigation, or to communicate with other
			 vehicles or infrastructure.

Vehicle-to-vehicle or vehicle-to-infrastructure communication systems for the purposes of recording
			 or transmitting or storing for later retrieval location, registration,
			 identity, or speed data are prohibited, except for those vehicles owned or
			 leased by Federal Government agencies in question.

Any such transmissions may only be used for momentary accident avoidance or completely anonymized
			 traffic reporting.
